doc.title: EMBOSS

description.text: European Molecular Biology Open Software Suite

doc.reference: EMBOSS: The European Molecular Biology Open Software Suite (2000) Rice,P. Longden,I. and Bleasby, A. Trends in Genetics 16, (6) pp276--277

description.text: Finds and extracts open reading frames (ORFs)

fieldset.title: This parameter is mandatory
fieldset.data-formats: EMBL FASTA GCG GENBANK NBRF CODATA RAW SWISSPROT GFF

xhtml:div.label: Genetic codes Standard Standard (with alternative initiation codons) Vertebrate mitochondrial Yeast mitochondrial Mold, protozoan, coelenterate mitochondrial and mycoplasma/spiroplasma Invertebrate mitochondrial Ciliate macronuclear and dasycladacean Echinoderm mitochondrial Euplotid nuclear Bacterial Alternative yeast nuclear Ascidian mitochondrial Flatworm mitochondrial Blepharisma macronuclear Chlorophycean mitochondrial Trematode mitochondrial Scenedesmus obliquus Thraustochytrium mitochondrial
Minimum nucleotide size of orf to report
Maximum nucleotide size of orf to report

Type of sequence to output?
Translation of regions between stop codons Translation of regions between start and stop codons Nucleic sequences between stop codons Nucleic sequences between start and stop codons Nucleotides flanking start codons Nucleotides flanking initial stop codons Nucleotides flanking ending stop codons
This is a small menu of possible output options. The first four options are to select either the protein translation or the original nucleic acid sequence of the open reading frame. There are two possible definitions of an open reading frame: it can either be a region that is free of STOP codons or a region that begins with a START codon and ends with a STOP codon. The last three options are probably only of interest to people who wish to investigate the statistical properties of the regions around potential START or STOP codons. The last option assumes that ORF lengths are calculated between two STOP codons.

Change initial start codons to methionine?
Yes No
START codons at the beginning of protein products will usually code for Methionine, despite what the codon will code for when it is internal to a protein. This qualifier sets all such START codons to code for Methionine by default.
Is the sequence circular Yes No

Find orfs in the reverse sequence?
Yes No
Set this to be false if you do not wish to find ORFs in the reverse complement of the sequence.

Number of flanking nucleotides to report?
If you have chosen one of the options of the type of sequence to find that gives the flanking sequence around a STOP or START codon, this allows you to set the number of nucleotides either side of that codon to output. If the region of flanking nucleotides crosses the start or end of the sequence, no output is given for this codon.
Name of the output sequence file (e_outseq)
Choose the sequence output format Embl Fasta Gcg Genbank Nbrf Codata Raw Swissprot Gff

div.title: This parameter is mandatory
div.data-formats: EMBL FASTA GCG GENBANK NBRF CODATA RAW SWISSPROT GFF

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This is a small menu of possible output options. The first four options are to select either the protein translation or the original nucleic acid sequence of the open reading frame. There are two possible definitions of an open reading frame: it can either be a region that is free of STOP codons or a region that begins with a START codon and ends with a STOP codon. The last three options are probably only of interest to people who wish to investigate the statistical properties of the regions around potential START or STOP codons. The last option assumes that ORF lengths are calculated between two STOP codons.

START codons at the beginning of protein products will usually code for Methionine, despite what the codon will code for when it is internal to a protein. This qualifier sets all such START codons to code for Methionine by default.
Set this to be false if you do not wish to find ORFs in the reverse complement of the sequence.

If you have chosen one of the options of the type of sequence to find that gives the flanking sequence around a STOP or START codon, this allows you to set the number of nucleotides either side of that codon to output. If the region of flanking nucleotides crosses the start or end of the sequence, no output is given for this codon.

comment.text: This is a small menu of possible output options. The first four options are to select either the protein translation or the original nucleic acid sequence of the open reading frame. There are two possible definitions of an open reading frame: it can either be a region that is free of STOP codons or a region that begins with a START codon and ends with a STOP codon. The last three options are probably only of interest to people who wish to investigate the statistical properties of the regions around potential START or STOP codons. The last option assumes that ORF lengths are calculated between two STOP codons.
